channel.title: Loading/Saving
channel.description:
what's going on with that? just logged in, out and it didn't save anything.
edit: nvm i see it's set to the dummy classes.

item.title: Loading/Saving
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:427737”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=530427.msg3874020#msg3874020 date=1325536836]

That probably shouldn’t be the default should it?
[/quote]I kind of like it. It’s useful for testing, and I don’t need to start Apache and MySQL.

That shouldn’t be the default either, didn’t one of Joe’s commits enable SQLite or Hibernate or some other type of local, persistent storage that doesn’t require a server? That should be the default.[/quote]You can create your own by implementing an interface. I was going to add Hibernate support, but I couldn’t get it running on SE.

[quote=“xEnt, post:6, topic:427737”]yeah its pretty bad setup atm. it only took a few mins to write a SerializedStorageMedium which works fine for development.[/quote]You should submit a pull request with it.

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:7, topic:427737”]Joes commit is for mysql binary storage, which is not completed.[/quote]Only the binary storage is incomplete (from the looks of it), and you can easily implement a new ‘DataStore’. Though, it doesn’t deal with saving/loading, that’s just for the things saved in XML ATM. What is being discussed is the ‘storage medium’, which is used for saving/loading by the LS.

Read full topic

item.title: Loading/Saving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:4, topic:427737”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=530427.msg3873474#msg3873474 date=1325513571]
That probably shouldn’t be the default should it?
[/quote]I kind of like it. It’s useful for testing, and I don’t need to start Apache and MySQL.[/quote]

That shouldn’t be the default either, didn’t one of Joe’s commits enable SQLite or Hibernate or some other type of local, persistent storage that doesn’t require a server? That should be the default.

Read full topic
